Award.AwardTitle: CER: Import PCK: What 10K Novice Teachers Can Learn from Teachers with 10K Hours of Experience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Harvey Mudd College will convene expert computer science (CS) educators to collaboratively document refine, and publish pedagogical content knowledge resources related to ninety topics in computer science. The central goal of the project is to document, validate, and promote CS pedagogical content knowledge, the combined knowledge of both the CS learner and CS content that enables an expert teacher to teach well. Resources developed will enable novice teachers to perform the actions of a more advanced CS teacher, such as incorporating new teaching practices, anticipating students? difficulties, and building upon students' strengths. In addition to this practical contribution, this research will identify open research questions in CS education.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to develop a set of computer science (CS) teaching tips to help teachers anticipate students’ difficulties and build upon students’ strengths. Before this project, CS pedagogical content knowledge (CS PCK) – i.e., knowledge of how to teach computer science – was mostly undocumented.

Intellectual Merit

The project has contributing to the research base within CS education by synthesizing pedagogical content knowledge in the field. The project team has:

  • Developed a website, CSTeachingTips.org to disseminate CS pedagogical content knowledge.
  • Generated 1294 tips for teaching CS from over 150 CS teachers.
  • Published seven research papers that developed pedagogical content knowledge (Chung, Shao, & Vasquez, 2017;Fishberg & Posner, 2015; Leake, 2015; Lewis, 2014; Lewis, Anderson, & Yasuhara, 2016; Lewis & Shah, 2015; Shah, Lewis, & Caires, 2014).
  • Published one research paper about the ways in which existing online communities and resources do and do not meet the needs of high-school teachers (Leake & Lewis, 2017).
  • Published one book chapter synthesizing research that motivates teaching CS (Lewis, 2017).
  • Prepared four other articles that have been accepted for publication.

Broader Impacts

This project has contributed to improving teaching practices beyond the immediate reach of the research. The project has:

  • Promoted CSTeachingTips.org resources through 31 invited talks, 5 webinars, 16 panels, 11 workshops, and 3 lightning talks.
  • Disseminated approximately 7,000 printed sets of the CSTeachingTips tip sheets (csteachingtips.org/tip-sheets) at conferences and professional development events.
  • Shared approximately three tips a day (a total of over 4,500) to over 5,000 followers on Twitter and over 700 page-likes on Facebook.
  • Provided summer research positions for 29 undergraduates, 25 of whom are underrepresented in CS because of their gender and/or race.

Publications

Chung, A., Shao, P., & Vasquez, A. (2017). Students' misconceptions about the types of values data structures can store. Journal of Computing Sciences in Colleges, 32(4), 72-78.

Fishberg, A. J., & Posner, S. A. (2015). Neo-piagetian reasoning and abstraction: introducing low-level programming to novice students. Journal of Computing Sciences in Colleges, 30(4), 92-99.

Leake, M. (2015). Chart-based strategies for solving Bayesian inference problems. Journal of Computing Sciences in Colleges, 30(4), 107-114.

Leake, M. & Lewis, C. M. (2017) Recommendations for Designing CS Resource Sharing Sites for All Teachers. ACM SIGCSE Bulletin. 48(1), 357-362.

Lewis, C. M. (2014). Exploring variation in students' correct traces of linear recursion. Proceedings of the International Computer Science Education Research Workshop. Glasgow, UK. 67-74.

Lewis, C. M. (2017). Good (and bad) reasons to teach all students computer science.  In S. B. Fee, A. M. Holland-Minkley, & T. E. Lombardi, New Directions for Computing Education: Embedding Computing Across Disciplines. New York: Springer.  

Lewis, C. M., Anderson, R. E., & Yasuhara, K. (2016). "I don't code all day": Fitting in computer science when the stereotypes don't fit. Proceedings of the International Computer Science Education Research Workshop. 23-32.

Lewis, C. M. & Shah, N. (2015). How Equity and Inequity Can Emerge in Pair Programming. Proceedings of the eleventh annual International Conference on International Computing Education Research (pp. 41-50).

Shah, N., Lewis, C. M., & Caires, R. (2014) Analyzing Equity in Collaborative Learning Situations: A Comparative Case Study in Elementary Computer Science. International Conferences of the Learning Sciences (ICLS). 495-502.
